Unhealthy Last Updated: 25 Dec 2025, 07:59am The problem of air pollution in Bangalore has risen in the last few years. Fourteen areas including Central Silk Board Junction, Domlur Circle, and ITPL Whitefield Road experience particulate concentrations greater than the national standards. The major reasons behind Bangalore\\'s increasing air pollution are vehicular pollution, increasing population density, development and changing landscape and use of diesel generators for electricity. MAJOR AIR POLLUTANTS In BANGALORE 99 (PM2.5) 135 (PM10) 2 (SO2) 11 (OZONE) 12 (NO2) AIR POLLUTION LEVEL IN INDIA MOST POLLUTED CITIES IN INDIA LEAST POLLUTED CITIES IN INDIA MAJOR CITIES IN INDIA Powered By locations status aqi-in pm2.5 pm10 temp humid Load More+ FAQs (Frequently Asked Questions) What is the current AQI level for Bengaluru? Currently, the air quality index for Bengaluru is 32, which is considered to be Good. What are the health effects of high AQI levels? High AQI levels can cause irritations in the eyes, nose, and throat, lung and heart diseases, and can also lead to premature death. What are the recommended AQI levels for Bengaluru? The recommended AQI levels for Bengaluru are less than 50 micrograms per cubic metre. Are there steps being taken to reduce air pollution in Bangalore? Several steps are being taken to level down the air pollution in Bangalore, Some of them are: Restrict the use of two-stroke vehicles. Monitor emissions on-road, with remote sensors for PUC (Pollution Under Control) certification. Promote use of battery-operated vehicles. Routinely calibrate the equipment in emission testing centres. Retrofit particulate filters in diesel vehicles. globals_schema.formatted_aqi_result_T003:
Bangalore Air Quality Index on December 25th, 2025

Executive Summary

The Air Quality Index (AQI) for Bangalore on December 25th, 2025, at 07:59am was reported as Unhealthy (230). This indicates a high level of air pollution, posing potential health risks to the population.

Detailed Findings

Based on available data, the AQI in Bangalore at 07:59am on December 25th, 2025, was 230, categorized as Unhealthy. This reading was taken in Bangalore.

Supporting Data

The following data sources were consulted in the preparation of this report:

  • aqi.in
  • aqicn.org
  • ews.tropmet.res.in
  • air-quality.com
  • news18.com

AQI Levels and Health Implications

According to the World Air Quality Index project, the following health implications are associated with different AQI levels:

AQI Air Pollution Level Health Implications Cautionary Statement (for PM2.5)
0 - 50 Good Air quality is considered satisfactory, and air pollution poses little or no risk None
51 - 100 Moderate Air quality is acceptable; however, for some pollutants there may be a moderate health concern for a very small number of people who are unusually sensitive to air pollution. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion.
101-150 Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups Members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. The general public is not likely to be affected. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion.
151-200 Unhealthy Everyone may begin to experience health effects; members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should avoid prolonged outdoor exertion; everyone else, especially children, should limit outdoor exertion
201-300 Very Unhealthy Health warnings of emergency conditions. The entire population is more likely to be affected. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should avoid all outdoor exertion; everyone else, especially children, should limit outdoor exertion.
300+ Hazardous Health alert: everyone may experience more serious health effects Everyone should avoid all outdoor exertion

Recommendations

Given the Unhealthy AQI level, it is recommended that individuals, especially sensitive groups (children, the elderly, and those with respiratory issues), limit prolonged outdoor exertion. The general public should also limit outdoor activities. Consider using air purifiers indoors.

Appendix

Data Sources

  • Raw AQI Data (See `all_globals_schema`)

nodes.description: Retrieve AQI data for Bangalore on 2025-12-22.
nodes.agent_prompt: Fetch Air Quality Index (AQI) data specifically for Bangalore on December 22nd, 2025. Focus on retrieving the AQI value and any available details regarding the measurement location and time.

nodes.description: Extract the AQI value from the retrieved data.
nodes.agent_prompt: Analyze the `raw_aqi_data_T001` and extract the AQI value for Bangalore on December 22nd, 2025. If available, also extract the measurement location and timestamp.

nodes.description: Format the AQI data into a human-readable sentence.
nodes.agent_prompt: Create a concise and readable sentence that presents the AQI value for Bangalore on December 22nd, 2025. Use the extracted values from `aqi_value_T002`, `aqi_location_T002`, and `aqi_timestamp_T002`. If the location or timestamp is not available, state that the AQI is for Bangalore on December 22nd, 2025, without specifying the precise location or timestamp.

nodes.description: Retrieve AQI data for Bangalore on 2025-12-22.
nodes.agent_prompt: Fetch Air Quality Index (AQI) data specifically for Bangalore on December 22nd, 2025. Focus on retrieving the AQI value and any available details regarding the measurement location and time.

code_variants.CODE_1A:
data = json.loads(search_web_with_text_content('Air Quality Index Bangalore December 22 2025', 5))
return {'raw_aqi_data_T001': data}
code_variants.CODE_1B:
urls = json.loads(fetch_search_urls('AQI Bangalore December 22 2025', 5))
return {'raw_aqi_data_T001': urls}

output.formatted_aqi_result_T003:
Bangalore Air Quality Index on December 25th, 2025

Executive Summary

The Air Quality Index (AQI) for Bangalore on December 25th, 2025, at 07:59am was reported as Unhealthy (230). This indicates a high level of air pollution, posing potential health risks to the population.

Detailed Findings

Based on available data, the AQI in Bangalore at 07:59am on December 25th, 2025, was 230, categorized as Unhealthy. This reading was taken in Bangalore.

Supporting Data

The following data sources were consulted in the preparation of this report:

  • aqi.in
  • aqicn.org
  • ews.tropmet.res.in
  • air-quality.com
  • news18.com

AQI Levels and Health Implications

According to the World Air Quality Index project, the following health implications are associated with different AQI levels:

AQI Air Pollution Level Health Implications Cautionary Statement (for PM2.5)
0 - 50 Good Air quality is considered satisfactory, and air pollution poses little or no risk None
51 - 100 Moderate Air quality is acceptable; however, for some pollutants there may be a moderate health concern for a very small number of people who are unusually sensitive to air pollution. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion.
101-150 Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups Members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. The general public is not likely to be affected. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion.
151-200 Unhealthy Everyone may begin to experience health effects; members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should avoid prolonged outdoor exertion; everyone else, especially children, should limit outdoor exertion
201-300 Very Unhealthy Health warnings of emergency conditions. The entire population is more likely to be affected. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should avoid all outdoor exertion; everyone else, especially children, should limit outdoor exertion.
300+ Hazardous Health alert: everyone may experience more serious health effects Everyone should avoid all outdoor exertion

Recommendations

Given the Unhealthy AQI level, it is recommended that individuals, especially sensitive groups (children, the elderly, and those with respiratory issues), limit prolonged outdoor exertion. The general public should also limit outdoor activities. Consider using air purifiers indoors.

Appendix

Data Sources

  • Raw AQI Data (See `all_globals_schema`)

output.formatted_aqi_result_T003:
Bangalore Air Quality Index on December 25th, 2025

Executive Summary

The Air Quality Index (AQI) for Bangalore on December 25th, 2025, at 07:59am was reported as Unhealthy (230). This indicates a high level of air pollution, posing potential health risks to the population.

Detailed Findings

Based on available data, the AQI in Bangalore at 07:59am on December 25th, 2025, was 230, categorized as Unhealthy. This reading was taken in Bangalore.

Supporting Data

The following data sources were consulted in the preparation of this report:

  • aqi.in
  • aqicn.org
  • ews.tropmet.res.in
  • air-quality.com
  • news18.com

AQI Levels and Health Implications

According to the World Air Quality Index project, the following health implications are associated with different AQI levels:

AQI Air Pollution Level Health Implications Cautionary Statement (for PM2.5)
0 - 50 Good Air quality is considered satisfactory, and air pollution poses little or no risk None
51 - 100 Moderate Air quality is acceptable; however, for some pollutants there may be a moderate health concern for a very small number of people who are unusually sensitive to air pollution. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion.
101-150 Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups Members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. The general public is not likely to be affected. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should limit prolonged outdoor exertion.
151-200 Unhealthy Everyone may begin to experience health effects; members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should avoid prolonged outdoor exertion; everyone else, especially children, should limit outdoor exertion
201-300 Very Unhealthy Health warnings of emergency conditions. The entire population is more likely to be affected. Active children and adults, and people with respiratory disease, such as asthma, should avoid all outdoor exertion; everyone else, especially children, should limit outdoor exertion.
300+ Hazardous Health alert: everyone may experience more serious health effects Everyone should avoid all outdoor exertion

Recommendations

Given the Unhealthy AQI level, it is recommended that individuals, especially sensitive groups (children, the elderly, and those with respiratory issues), limit prolonged outdoor exertion. The general public should also limit outdoor activities. Consider using air purifiers indoors.

  • Raw AQI Data (See `all_globals_schema`)
